Fix a category C\mathscr{C}C. Every map f:X→Yf: X \rightarrow Yf:X→Y in C\mathscr{C}C induces a functor f!:C/X→C/Yf_!: \mathscr{C}/X \rightarrow \mathscr{C}/Yf!​:C/X→C/Y given by composing with fff (i.e. the dependent sum, although no pullbacks are required in C\mathscr{C}C). Furthermore, this functor commutes with the domain projections C/X→C\mathscr{C}/X \rightarrow \mathscr{C}C/X→C and C/Y→C\mathscr{C}/Y \rightarrow \mathscr{C}C/Y→C. So we can define the 'slice Yoneda' functor Y:C→CAT/C\mathscr{Y}: \mathscr{C} \rightarrow \text{CAT}/\mathscr{C}Y:C→CAT/C by sending XXX to C/X→domC\mathscr{C}/X \xrightarrow{\text{dom}} \mathscr{C}C/Xdom​C and f:X→Yf: X \rightarrow Yf:X→Y to f!f_!f!​. This bears a strong resemblance to the usual Yoneda embedding C→[Cop,Set]\mathscr{C} \rightarrow [\mathscr{C}^\text{op}, \text{Set}]C→[Cop,Set] although it doesn't seem to be mentioned in any of the usual textbook treatments.

This functor Y\mathscr{Y}Y is obviously faithful since if we had f!=g!:C/X→C/Yf_! = g_!: \mathscr{C}/X \rightarrow \mathscr{C}/Yf!​=g!​:C/X→C/Y, we could apply them to 1X1_X1X​ to get f=gf = gf=g. I'm trying to prove that Y\mathscr{Y}Y is also full but I can't seem to figure it out (although I feel like I'm missing something obvious).

Also, is there an analogue in this situation to the usual Yoneda lemma Hom(Y(X),F)≅F(X)\text{Hom}(\mathscr{Y}(X), F) \cong F(X)Hom(Y(X),F)≅F(X)?
In this case, FFF would represent a functor F:A→CF: \mathscr{A} \rightarrow \mathscr{C}F:A→C instead of a presheaf on C\mathscr{C}C and so Hom(Y(X),F)\text{Hom}(\mathscr{Y}(X), F)Hom(Y(X),F) would represent the set (or category?) of functors C/X→A\mathscr{C}/X \rightarrow \mathscr{A}C/X→A commuting with the functors down to C\mathscr{C}C (the domain projection and FFF respectively).

There's an isomorphism between the category of presheaves on C and the category of discrete fibrations over C (which are in particular functors into C), so you can always rephrase results about presheaves (e.g. Yoneda) in terms of discrete fibrations.

A discrete fibration is a fibration with discrete fibers, i.e. every fiber is a set, i.e. there are no non-trivial morphisms. The fiber of C/X→C\mathscr C/X \to \mathscr CC/X→C over an object YYY is given by the category of morphisms Y→XY \to XY→X, which is not a set since endomorphisms Y→YY \to YY→Y induce morphisms between morphisms Y→XY \to XY→X

I think I've got it! :party_ball:
The idea is to notice that the usual Yoneda lemma is sending XXX to the functor assigning to every AAA it set of generalized elements, while the fiber of C/X→C\mathscr C/X \to \mathscr CC/X→C over AAA has more information, as noted above, namely it is a category.
Therefore instead of looking at the functor C(−,X):Cop→Set\mathscr C(-, X) : \mathscr C^{op} \to \mathbf{Set}C(−,X):Cop→Set, we should look at the functor −/X:Cop→Cat-/X : \mathscr C^{op} \to \mathbf{Cat}−/X:Cop→Cat, where I'm abusing the slice notation: now A/XA/XA/X, where A∈CA \in \mathscr CA∈C, is the full subcategory of C/X\mathscr C/XC/X determined by those arrows with source AAA. Equivalently, A/XA/XA/X is the fiber over AAA of the domain fibration.
Then the Yoneda embedding is into the category of pseudofunctors [Cop,Cat][\mathscr C^{op}, \mathbf{Cat}][Cop,Cat] (which is a bicategory whose 1-morphisms are pseudonatural transformations and whose 2-cells are modifications), and Yoneda lemma says [Cop,Cat](−/X,F)≃F(X)\mathscr C^{op}, \mathbf{Cat} \simeq F(X)[Cop,Cat](−/X,F)≃F(X) where notice we replace 'natural isomorphism' with 'natural equivalence', since this is the appropriate notion of 'equality' at this level.
The above works since it's a special case of the bicategorical Yoneda lemma (see Yau and Johnson's book referenced there for a detailed account)! Indeed, every (1-)category is a bicategory with trivial 2-morphisms. Nevertheless, as you noticed, in doing so we resume a bunch of 1-categorical structure that's lost in the 1-Yoneda lemma.
Finally, a note on the fibrational interpretation: as someone noted above, presheaves over a category C\mathscr CC are the same thing as discrete fibrations, i.e. fibrations over C\mathscr CC such that its fibers are sets. This is however an unnatural way to describe the usual Yoneda embedding, which is very elegantly defined as sending XXX to its representable functor, which is a functor Cop→Set\mathscr C^{op} \to \mathbf{Set}Cop→Set.
In the new setting though, the fibrational interpretation of [Cop,Cat][\mathscr C^{op}, \mathbf{Cat}][Cop,Cat] is actually more natural. The Grothendieck construction says this category is equivalent to Fib(C)\mathbf{Fib}(\mathscr C)Fib(C), the category of fibrations over CCC. These fibrations do not have any restriction on the nature of the fiber.
I said this is more natural since A/XA/XA/X, as noted above, is desperate to be defined as the fiber of C/X→domX\mathscr C/X \overset{dom}\to XC/X→domX, so the image of XXX under the augmented Yoneda embedding is more readily defined as the domain fibration of the slice over XXX.
